Game is designed for multiplayer, but plays decently well in singleplayer. Process of initially building up your base, crafting gear, taming animals and exploring the map is really fun and exciting. The high chance of death when exploring and dangerous creatures lurking in the map always keeps you on your toes, no matter how far into the game you have progressed. The story is surprisingly interesting and I love the fact that you have an actual end goal - killing all the bosses. The soundtrack is easily the best thing about this game, it has blockbuster movie levels of production quality.

However, some of these mechanics can become quite tedious near the lategame-endgame section. Crafting recipes end up becoming really expensive with no major ways of making the resource collection process more efficient. Dying to random bullshit becomes much more common and retrieving/recrafting your items turns into a massive time sink. There are a lot of bugs in the game, and while 99% of them are not game-breaking, they still detract from the experience and make things infuriating when they really shouldn't be.

But to be honest these issues only really exist because you're supposed to play with others, so I would highly recommend playing this game with friends. Most of the mechanics are balanced well in singleplayer, with the default single player settings. The only major exception would be the Snow Cave, which was basically impossible for me to complete alone without God mode - Enemies are so spongy and bringing a group of Theris is really difficult given how they constantly get stuck in parts of the cave. Mods may fix these issues, but I wouldn't know since I only played vanilla.

My point of view is someone who had never played this before, somehow missing / ignoring it the last 10 years!  So, I don't have any frame of reference for the drama around Aquatica release, the mod situations at that time, etc.  That said, my wife and son and I have spent the last 45 days having a really fun time in Ark on the Island map with our own private server.  We are up to 14 mods, and even though many haven't been updated in years, the ones we use all seem to work fine on the current Aquatica branch of the base game.  It did take quite a bit of work to get our INI files and mod situation sorted at the beginning to give ourselves a fair challenge but not be so grindy.  Boosting stack sizes and weight stat gains in the INIs was a huge QOL upgrade, as well as overall taming / breeding time reductions.   After 45 days, we've beaten the 3 Alpha bosses but haven't yet tried Overseer, hoping to do that this weekend.  Overall I think this is still a very fun game.  My only real complaints are around the building system, which is far more archaic and annoying compared to the games that came later in this genre.  I'm hesitant to install a building mod though, as I've read horror stories of the mod failing to load or other glitchy behavior and losing all your buildings.

ARK: Survival Evolved is a large open-world survival game where players must gather resources, build bases, and tame dinosaurs in order to survive in a dangerous prehistoric environment. The variety of biomes, creatures, and items keeps the gameplay interesting, while breeding, boss fights, and technology progression provide long-term goals. Playing with friends on co-op or PvP servers makes the experience even more exciting and unpredictable. However, the game is heavily criticized for its poor optimization, frequent bugs, long loading times, and occasional server problems, especially on weaker PCs and consoles. With better performance, stronger stability, and a more polished user interface, ARK could reach its full potential as one of the best survival games available.

Well, there are several significant downsides.

Very poor optimization ‚Äì even powerful PCs can experience FPS drops and stuttering
Large number of bugs and glitches that can break gameplay
Extremely large game size and long installation/loading times
Frequent crashes and server instability on official servers
Unbalanced gameplay in PvP (experienced players dominate new players)
Complicated and sometimes frustrating inventory and crafting system
Steep learning curve with little in-game guidance

ARK used to be about surviving dinosaurs. Now it feels like I‚Äôm surviving Snail Games‚Äô monetization decisions.

When ARK: Survival Ascended launched, I genuinely hoped this was a fresh start ‚Äî a chance to rebuild the game on a modern engine, fix decade-long bugs, and wipe the slate clean. Instead, it‚Äôs been a parade of half-finished content drops, paid DLC before the base game is even stable, and a constant feeling that players are being monetized first and listened to last.

The new Aquatica DLC should‚Äôve been exciting. A map focused on underwater exploration, new creatures, new environments ‚Äî finally something different. Instead, it feels rushed, unoptimized, and unfinished. Performance tanks constantly, even on strong hardware. Underwater FPS swings between ‚Äúslideshow‚Äù and ‚ÄúPowerPoint presentation.‚Äù There are floating foliage meshes, invisible collision, dinos spawning inside geometry, terrain holes, missing polish, repetitive biomes, and creatures with broken AI. It‚Äôs like someone exported the map from the editor and said ‚Äúship it.‚Äù

What makes it worse is that many of these issues existed in older maps. We already reported them. We already lived through them. Buying a DLC shouldn‚Äôt mean paying for recycled bugs.

It‚Äôs painfully obvious what the priority is: push out paid content as fast as possible instead of fixing the base game. Critical bugs from launch are still here. Server stability is bad. Balance issues go untouched. UI problems linger. Networking issues are constant. But new paid DLC? That arrives right on schedule. Players shouldn‚Äôt have to pay to beta test content inside a game that itself still feels like a beta.

The community has carried this franchise for years. We tolerated jank, bugs, lag, wipes, disappearing tames, rubberbanding, and servers melting during events ‚Äî because we believed the game would eventually improve and that loyalty would be rewarded. Instead we got higher prices, paid DLC before the game is finished, cosmetic monetization, bundles, cross-promotion, and marketing hype, while stability and core fixes feel like an afterthought.

Wildcard clearly has talent ‚Äî the creature designs and ideas are great. But it feels like every creative decision gets overshadowed by Snail Games‚Äô desire to monetize as aggressively and as early as possible. ARK could be incredible if the priority was finishing systems and supporting the community instead of cranking out the next DLC.

The saddest part is that this could have been the definitive version of ARK. Instead, it‚Äôs becoming a cautionary tale about what happens when a publisher prioritizes revenue over quality.

If you‚Äôre considering buying the Aquatica DLC, ask yourself this: do you want to pay to test another unfinished map while the base game still struggles to run correctly?

Until the focus shifts from monetization to actually finishing the game: ‚ùå Do not recommend.

Genuinely the most infuriating survival game I have ever played. This is such a cool concept let down by terrible mechanics that have remained unchanged for God only knows what reason.

This game is tedium incarnate. Building pieces have to crafted one at a time, then placed into the hotbar, before you can place them. There is also no crafting from storage, meaning you are constantly running back and forth.

Everything is also way too expensive, with even the most basic items requiring tens of resources to craft. There's also no way to decrease crafting requirements, only increasing the amount of resources you can gather. This, ironically, just makes crafting and building take longer since you get encumbered faster.

Even with mods, there are just too many smaller issues that add up to a frustrating experience. Perhaps I just haven't found the right mods, but that just makes the problem worse if you need to hunt for mods that add basic functions other survival games have had for years.

And don't even get me started on the game's insane size. 160GB for JUST the base game is a level of ridiculous that would make the COD devs blush.

It also doesn't seem like the unnecessary remaster has improved the game at all, possibly even made it worse. Honestly, there are so many other survival games that are better in pretty much every way. Just go play them.

People think this is fun?

The Good:
- The (oversized) velociraptor analogues have feathers

The Bad:
 - Literally everything else

The Ugly:
- Animation quality straight out of 1996
- Control maps reminiscent of 1994
- The inventory flashing "hologram" projector would give anyone a seizure
- The music is SO LOUD (and overly dramatic)
- UI design that will give you carpal tunnel in a day
- More death than a Hidetaka MIyazaki game
- More bugs than a Men In Black movie villain's barn

I heard SO MANY great things about ARK. Critically acclaimed and rave reviews. I'm not a *big* fan of the "Survival Game" genre, but after having played a few others and gotten an idea for what I do and don't enjoy, I thought it was time to give this a try. 

Because WHO DOESN'T WANT TO RIDE THEIR OWN PET FRIGGIN DINOSAUR??????

Start up the game and the very first thing I notice is the game defaults to Windowed mode at 2/3 my native resolution. The second thing I noticed was that I couldn't click on anything and the game's main menu was completely non-responsive. Eventually it did start responding, not because of anything I did though. Even after it started responding it was still very laggy and would go unresponsive for several seconds at a time. 

The menu and options screens are cluttered and confusing, even to a veteran gamer. But poor UI design is a staple of modern computing, since everyone started learning to code from Stack Overflow and stopped going to school for it. Still, I *expect* more from a popular video game. 

The menu includes a survival guide. That's not a good sign. If you have to put a how-to guide in your menu, it means you didn't balance the intro / tutorial experience very well; or in this case didn't include one at all. 

The process of starting a new game is ... a LOT. Having come from setting up dedicated servers for a few other survival crafting games, I wasn't as intimidated as I might have been 6 months ago, but players new to the genre would absolutely be crushed and confused by all of the "Single player" server and world options. The character creation process is... lackluster. You kind of get to customize your character's appearance, but that boils down to an amateurish bone scale along a 2D plane for a half dozen body parts and changing eye, skin, and hair color along a spectrum that all kind of looks like the same color of mud. 

After all that and finally getting into the game proper, the real question is whether the core gameplay loop and structural mechanics are engaging enough to keep playing. 
They aren't. 
Even on EASY mode in an EASY start area, you die before you even figure out how to craft anything. And that's after having read the survival guide before playing. You start out unable to craft any meaningful weapons or armor, much less a shelter or even a camp fire. Therefore you die. A lot. And even on "easy mode" there are raptors and spinosaurus and piranhas hanging around your spawn location. And mobs that kill you have a tendency to camp your body, so good luck getting any of your inventory back.

Assuming there's anything worth recovering in your inventory anyway. You have to get your "engrams" before you can craft anything, and that's where the mechanics really break down into garbage. 

In order to learn to craft anything, you have to spend "Engram points" on an "Engram" that is the game's method for learning new crafting recipes. The limited number of Engram points available and inability to easily reassign them (especially early on) encourages players to save their Engram points for the better later-game crafting options. The result is a crafting system that actively discourages players from crafting. 

But then, I had to play, and die a lot, for an hour before I figured out how to even spend Engram points and get new crafting recipes in the first place. 

Engrams aren't just bought with Engram points, you have to unlock them first. The only way I found to unlock unknown Engrams was to get them in a "Supply crate". Again, the game's mechanics break down here, as supply crates are fairly rare, spawn for a limited time, and many of the crates that spawn are higher level than your character (even in a single player game) - making them completely unavailable to you even if you're able to find and reach one. This, again, discourages players from playing the game, since every supply crate has a moderate to high chance of being unusable anyway. 

The controls are wonky with a few non-standard key mapping decisions that drive me up the wall. (TAB hasn't been the key for opening the console in a game since 1997. And C hasn't been used to crouch since 2004.)

The dinosaurs are gorgeous but would disappoint YDAW (admittedly resulting in an entertaining youtube video). (OK, but seriously, your raptors are 8 feet tall, fine, you watched too much Jurassic Park and I can forgive that. And at least you put feathers on them. Sort of. But then you orient your thagomizers upright like you used a dollar store stego toy from 1985 as your model. Guys. Seriously. We've known thagomizers are oriented horizontally since 1993.) And while the dinosaur animations look OK (for the most part), the character animations look like they were rigged and animated by a teenage intern from the 90s using Blender for the very first time. (Zoom out to third person and punch something. Then watch a real person punch something. Then laugh. Or cry, depending.)

The resource gathering is tedious, the HUD is barely visible, lacks any kind of crosshair or easy way to tell what you're looking at, focused on, or in range of, the sound effects are incongruous, and no, you do NOT use a pickaxe to dress a carcass. Assuming you manage to kill anything before it kills you. 

And for those of you reading this and screaming at your monitors that "It's a *survival* game, staying alive is *supposed* to be hard", yes, I know, but even the most hard core survival game needs to keep players alive long enough for them to learn the basic mechanics and *how* to survive, and this is *not* a "hard core" survival game. 

Long story short - I had really high hopes for this game, but it's 100% disappointment. And I would still love to tame and ride my own dinosaur, but this is not the game where that will happen.
